section: Section 30—Court is not empowered or  authorized to waive interest charged on the amount                  under claim as per agreement executed between the  judgment debtor and the financial institution i.c. .(hc  plaintiff-Bank till its realization. The contemplation  of the aforesaid provision of law is clear and  unambiguous that the Court cannot waive such  interest and it is the Bank itself who could waive  such interest to whom the defendant could approach  for waiving the interest.    Section 30 of the Bank Companies Act, 199’1  has also imposed similar embargo upon the Court's  jurisdiction to interfere with the interest so payable  -b_\' the borrower to the Bank under agreement,  although the Court had authority to grant installment  to the decretal amount subject to some limitations.  Jarate Bank vs Mohiuddin Specialised Textile  (Civil) 501

Section 17(6)—Mere re-scheduling of loan is  not enough to have a resort under section 17(6) to  restore the post of Director. The amount as shown in  the notice is not only 58.38 lakh rather it was a  installment one and the outstanding loan being a  ‘o B9 @™ was 1,456.50 lakh, which is to be  paid to have resort under section 17(6) of the Act.  Deen Mohammad vs Bangladesh Bank (Spl  Original)  506

Section 17(6)—There is nothing within the  four corners of section 17 of the Act, which goes to  favour the petitioner for restoring his position as  Director by simply rescheduling the loan on 10%  down payment which is more than the amount.  Because such reschedulement does not fulfill the  requirement of section 17(6) of the Act. Deen  Mohammad vs Bangladesh Bank (Spl Original) 506

Section 17(6)—Payment of notice amount by  way of re-scheduling loan after the statutory period  is not enough to restore the status of the petitioner or  to make him qualified as Director as contemplated  in section 17(6) of the Act, unless the entire amount  shown in the notice as “Tm B@if A" is paid for  the purpose of restoration of their qualification of  Director. Deen Mohammad vs Bangladesh Bank  (Spl Original)  506

title: Code of Civil Procedure
section: Order XXIII rule 1(2)(3)—It appears that  the Appellate Court without hearing the appeal on  merit only allowed the application under Order  XX, mic 1 Sub-rule 1(2) and passed the order  permiting to withdraw the suit. The plaint itself was  rejected by the trial Court and without hearing the  a;;pcnl on merit and allowing the application and  passing of the impugned order, on the face of it, the  anncllate Court has made a futile exercise of the  r\'o‘\\‘(‘r. in as much as, the plaint itself it not in  existence and thereby, as it appears the impugned  order was passed without application of mind which  has clearly occasioned failure of justice. Ramiz-    uddin vs Abdul Hamid (Civil) 434

Order XIII rule 8—Bainapatra has been  proved by the plaintiff, the same is required to be  impounded under the provision of Order XIII, rule 8  of the Code and accordingly, the appellate Court in  the impugned judgment passed an order for  impounding the Bainapatra and allowed the appeal  subject to payment of impounded stamp duty which  the plaintiff has already paid. It appears this lacuna  in the impugned Bainapatra for insufficiency of  stamp duty has been cured by the said impounding  order and in view of the provision of section 35 of  the Stamp Act, 1899 this Court finds that the  impugned Bainapatra was competent to be admitted  into evidence in this proceeding. Moreover, in view  of the provision of section 36 of the Stamp Act.  1899 and the decision of the case reported in 39  DLR 243, this Court finds that the appellate Court  correctly considered that the said Bainapatra as  admissible in evidence. Therefore, the argument that  the Bainapatra has been correctly admitted into  evidence by the trial Court as well as appellate  Court and the question of insufficiency of the stamp  duty has been properly addressed. Naimuddin Molla  vs Ibrahim Molla (Civil) 369

Order IX rule 13—The negligence of the  defendant and due to such negligence, the defendant  was not entitled to the relief prayed for under Order  IX, rule 13 of the Code. Gross negligence on the part  of the petitioner-defendant should stand in the way  of getting relief under Order IX, rule 13 of the Code  when the suit was rightly found to be barred by  limitation. Motiur Rahman vs AKM Shamsul Alamin  (Civil) 449

Order VI rule 1—The plaintiff is totally  Z‘lent about any hostile claim of right as against the  efendant Nos, 1-4. He did not specifically plead                  any claim of acquisition of title by adverse posses-  sion. From the pleadings of the parties it does not  appear that the plaintiff ever claimed any hostile title  against the said defendant in the examination-in-  chief. Umme Hani Begum vs Ram Gopal Sarker  (Civil) 17

Section 115(1)—It is well settled that CS  record has got a presumptive value though rebuttal  in nature. That is why in a title suit relating to land  Like the instant one, the plaintiff claims title by  narrating facts showing chain of title right from the  (S record. If the title is derived from a common  ancestor of the parties, still the stand of the ancestor  should be described in the pleading. If the common  ancestor is admittedly SA recorded tenant or a  tenant of some other record-of-right, the same must  also be narrated in the pleading because the Court,  in determining title, is to peruse such record-of-  right. The facts constituting chain of title of the  plaintiff/defendant must be narrated in the pleading  deducing the same from CS record, particularly  when the common ancestor in an heir of a CS  recorded tenant. In a title suit relating to land, the  derivation of title of the plaintiff/defendant is  Narrated in the pleading from the stage of CS record  as it forms the basis of title. Golam Beg vs Hajera  Begum (Civil) 452

Section 115—The Court  of appeal below without reversing the finding of  facts relating 10 service of summons arrived at by  the trial Court most erroncously held that without  examining opposite party No.21 Nurul Huda as to  the date of knowledge, the opposite party No.23  Abul Kashem failed to prove the date of  knowledge. This view of the Court of appeal below  is absolutely wrong, inasmuch as witness No.2 Abu  Taher categorically stated that in his presence  apposite party No.21 for the first time disclosed  about the land transferred to opposite party No.23.  Abul Kashem vs AKM Golam Mostafa (Civil) 44

Section 115—The Defence of Pakistan Ordi-  nance and Rules came in the year 1965 and both the  Ordinance and Rules were repealed in the year  1969, but by Ordinance No.1 of 1969 promulgated  by the then Central Government of Pakistan, some  of the Provisions of the Defence of Pakistan Rules  were kept alive and continued. Thereafter by Act  No.XLV of 1974, the Ordinance No.1 of 1969 Was  repealed on 23-3.1974. So, after the repeal Of  Ordinance No.1 of 1969 by Act No.XLV of 1974 on  23-3-1974, the authority was not competent to start  such vested property proceedings in the eye of law                    Bangladesh vS Rahima Begum (Civil) 430

Section 115—The High Court Division while  exercising its revisional jurisdiction is competent to  reverse the judgment of the Courts below when the  same has been made either upon misreading or non-  consideration of the material evidence causing  failure of justice. Jahangir Alam Chowdhury vs  Zabun Nahar Chowdhurani (Civil) 322

Section 115—Penalty like dismissal of ,  teacher from service cannot be imposed by e  Managing Committee of the School without Prior  approval of the TPEC. It appears from thc judgment,  of the lower appellate Court that the Joint District,  Judge did not consider this mandatory provison,, of  the government notification and .thereby he hag  committed as error of law resulting in an error i, the  decision occasioning failure of justice and, as such  on this score alone the judgment of the lower  appellate Court cannot be sustained in law. The,  plaintiff is not thus entitled to get the back salary as  admittedly she did not render her services to the  school since the date of her dismissal. Shefali Bala,  vs Khalipur Pukurpara Non-Government Primary  School (Civil) 41

Section 24—Transfer of appeal—It appears  that all the grounds of withdrawing of the appeal  from the Court of District Judge have been  mitigated and there is no apprehension of injustice if                  he appeal is withdrawn and transferred this  Court, rather such transfer will do justice to the  Parties. Saroj Kumar Sarker vs Monoj Kumar  Sarker (Civil) 25

Section 11—Res judicata—It appears that the  legality of either the Martial Law Proclamations or  that of the Fifth Amendment was not finally decided  in the Order summarily rejecting the Writ Petition  No. 802 of 1994. Such summary rejection does not  Cebar challenging of those provisions in a  subsequently filed writ petition, on the principle of  res judicata, since no such issue had been raised  therein or heard and finally decided by the said  Court. The sine qua non for application of the  principle of res judicata is the finality of a decision  in an earlier action. Since no rule was issued in the  Writ Petition No. 802 of 1994, the summary order  passed in the said writ petition in the absence of the  respondents therein, do not operate as res judicata in  the present writ petition. Jtalian Marb/e Works Lid  vs Bangladesh (Spl. Original) 70

title: Code of Criminal Procedure
section: Section 561A—A Court of law cannot  proceed judicially on a mere statement made by  police officer to the effect that a prima facie case  under certain penal provision has been proved  against the accused persons, without disclosing the  allegation of fact constituting the offence. Such a  statement, unaccompanied by the facts constituting  the said offence, which is nothing but a mere  opinion of police officer concerned, cannot be in  any event, the basis of any judicial action by the  Court. Sajeda Chowdhury vs State (Criminal) 441

Section 561 A—Neither the Senior Special  Judge, nor the Divisional Special Judge considered  the facts and 'materials available on record. Just the  case has been proceeded on the basis of the police  report which cannot be taken as basis unless it is  supported by any materials on record which can be  scrutinized at the time of taking of cognizance,  Syeda Sajeda Chowdhury vs State (Criminal) 44/

Section 561A—Quashing of Proceeding—  From a reading of the FIR, it appears that the  informant in writing made the statement that “আমি  ব্যবসা করার জন্য চুক্তি মোতাবেক মাহমুদুর রহমান   ব্যবস্থাপনা পরিচালক মেসার্স রহমান এ্যান্ড কো ং, From this statement  it appears that the said transaction was made under  an agreement and the narration of fact in the FIR  indicates also breach of terms of the agreement had  crept up from business transaction, It also appears  from the FIR that considerable amount, that is about  Taka 16,50,000, has already been paid by the  accused petitioner. We are of the view that no  criminal intention to cheat or to deceive the  informant by the petitioner has been made out by the  informant. The learned Advocate for the petitioner  cited the decisions reported in 1999 BLD (AD) 128      = 4 BLC (AD) 167, 26 DLR (SC) 17, 37 DLR g  207, 39 DLR 214, 1992 BLD 284 = 45 DLR 661  wherein it has been decided that if from a reading of  the FIR it comes up the allegations disclose Civil  linbility then the proceeding can be quashed. The  proceeding of GR Case No. 3735 of 2002 pending in  the Court of learned Chiel Metropolitan Magistrate‘  Dhaka is quashed. Mahamudur Rahman vs Md  Matiur Rahman (Criminal) 367

Section 561 A—Initiation of the criminal case  at the instance of the present complainant/informant  without taking recourse of the procedures provided  in Samabava Samity Ain, 2001, is not maintainable  in law. Since initiation of the case is barred by law,  this Court in exercise of its jurisdiction under  section 561A of the Code of Criminal Procedure can  quash the proceeding at its initial stage before taking  cognizance thereof. M Fransis P Rojario alias Babu  vs State (Criminal) 355

Section 561 A—Section S61A of the Code of  Criminal Procedure can exercise its inherent  jurisdiction for quashing a proceeding of a criminal  case firstly to make such orders as may be necessary  to give effect to any order of the Code, secondly to  prevent abuse of the process of the Court and lastly  otherwise to secure ends of justice. M Fransis P  Rosario alias Babu vs State (Criminal) 355

Section 561 A—Quashing of proceeding, not  before cognizance is taken—A criminal case  actually starts from the date of taking cognizance  and issuance of the process. Before cognizance is  taken, there is virtually no pending criminal  proceeding in the eye of law. So a non-existent                    criminal proceeding cannot be subject matter of  quashment. In this respect, decision of our apex  Court in the case of Abdul Haque vs State reported  in 60 DLR (AD) 1 may profitably be quoted,  Salahuddin Ahmed vs State (Criminal) 3517

Section 561 A—Defence plea—Defence plea  which, as per well sentled principle, is to be decided  by evidence before the trial Court and not a all a  ground for quashment. Barrister Mainul Hosein vs  Md Ali Hossain (Criminal) 38

Section 561A—Mere presence of an  arbitration clause in the agreement does bar  launching of 2 criminal case, if the complaint  discloses a prima facie case as evident from the case  reported in 2002 SCC (Cn) 129, SW Palanitkar vs  State of Bihar. Sheikh Mashuk Rahman vs State  (Criminal) 28

Section 561 A—Whether the notice as  required to be served under section 138 of  Negotiable Instruments Act is essentially 2 question  of fact to be proved by adducing evidence at the  time of trial, inasmuch as there is specific assertion  in the complaint petition that such 2 notice was.  served. Sheikh Mashuk vs State (Criminal) 28

title: Constitution (5th Amendment) Act, 1979
section: Section 2—Fourth Schedule—But even at the  time of revoking and repealing the Proclamations,  MLRs and MLOs by the Proclamation dated April 6,  1979, the Constitution was sought to be made  subordinate to the ‘Orders’ of the President. We  have no words to deplore and deprecate such  conduct. Thus, in the garb of this seemingly  innocent amendment, a fraud had been committed  upon the peoble of Bangladesh and their Constitu-  tion. Jtalian Marble Works Ltd vs Bangla-desh (Spl.  Original) 70

title: Criminal Law Amendment Act
section: Section 4—Court is to record the reasons for  discharging the accused under section 241A of the  Code, but no such reasons are required to be  recorded in farming charge against the accused as  per provisions of section 242 of the Code. section: Section 3—The Defence of Pakistan Ordi-  nance and Rules came in the year 1965 and both the  Ordinance and Rules were repealed in the year  1969, but by Ordinance No.1 of 1969 promulgated  by the then Central Government of Pakistan, some  of the Provisions of the Defence of Pakistan Rules  were kept alive and continued. section: Section 115—Estoppel—However, the fact is  that. the Matriculation Certificate of the plaintiff  was not corrected but there was an affidavit to the  effect that the date of his birth is 3-1-1945 and this  affidavit was accepted by the defendants and the  defendants allowed him to join the service and  allowed him to get salary for 36 years, and gave his  salary by MPO issued by the defendants for the last  20 years without any objection from anybody and it  was within the full knowledge of the defendants.  The defendants cannot be allowed to say that his  date of birth will be calculated on the basis of the  Matriculation Certificate and not from date shown  in his affidavit (Exhibit 3). It cannot be expected that  they will give evidence against the accused,  Moreover the accused in order to discharge his  obligation could examine them. All of them are his  men. But he did not do so. No adverse presumption  against the prosecution should be drawn for their    non-examination by the prosecution. State vs Azam  Reza (Criminal) 399

Section 106—Presence of the accused in the  house at the material time is not disputed. No plea of  alibi has been taken. Moreover presence of the  accused at the material time is supported by the  evidence on record. The death of the deceased was  in the special knowledge of the accused. Section 105—Defence plea—There is a basic  rule of criminal jurisprudence that if two views are  possible on the evidence adduced in a case of  circumstantial evidence, one pointing to the guilt of  the accused and the other to his innocence, the Court  should adopt the view favourabie to the accused. If  we consider the entire evidence we can safely  conclude that the prosecution has totally failed to  prove its case, moreso, the version put forward by  the defence has a reasonable possibility of being  true. Hence the accused is entitled to get benefit of  doubt, not as a matter of grace but as a matter of  right. Atahar vs State ( Criminal) ' 302

Such a confession can  only be used to lend assurance to other evidence  against a co-accused. The judge may call in aid the  confession and use it to lend assurance to the other  evidence. title: Negotiable Instruments Act [XXIV of 1881]
section: Section 138(1)(c)—Section 141(1)(b)—  Cause of action—Complaint petition—Since, in the  demand notice the total amount of the 3(three)  cheques amounting to Taka 12,84,600 has been  demanded and the drawer of the cheque having  failed to make payment of the "said amount of  money" within 30 days, only one cause of action has  arisen and, legally, for one cause of action there  should be one complaint petition, which has exactly  been done in the impugned proceeding.. Nurun Nabi  vs Md Abu Taher Khan (Criminal) 317

Section 138(1)(c)—Section 141(1)(b)—  Cause of action—<clause (b) of section 141, read  with sub-section (1) of section 138 of the Act,  clearly signifies that dishonour of a cheque per se  would not bring the drawer of the dishonoured  cheque within the mischief of sub-section (1) of  section 138. There must have arisen a cause of  action for taking cognizance under clause (1) of  section 141 of the Act. Such cause of action arises  upon failure of the drawer of cheque to make  payment of "the amount of money", within 30 days  of receiving the notice demanding payment of the  amount under the dishonoured cheque and not  within 30 days of dishonour of a cheque. Nurun  Nabi vs Md Abu Taher Khan (Criminal) 317

Section 138(1)(b)—Since the complainant  filed the complaint after expiry of the statutory  period of 30 days from the date of issuance of notice  under proviso of section 138(1)(b) of the Act and as  such taking cognizance of complaint by the  Magistrate was not legal and since taking of cogni-  zance is illegal, the continuation of the proceeding  will create abuse of the process of the Court. The facts narrated in the complaint do  constitute prima facie offence under section 138 of  the Act and as such, question of quashing the                  proceeding does not arise. In a suit for recovery  of possession under section 9 of the Specific Relief  Act, notwithstanding any other title that may be set  up in such a suit, the person dispossessed without  the consent or otherwise than in due course of law,  can claim recovery of the possession. title: Stamp Act (111 of 1899)
section: Section 35—Bainapatra has been proved by  the plaintiff, the same is required to be impounded  under the provision of Order XIII, rule 8 of the Code  and accordingly, the appellate. Court in the  impugned judgment passed an order for impounding  the Bainapatra and allowed the appeal subject 1o  payment of impounded stamp duty which the  plaintiff has already paid. It appears this lacuna in  the impugned Bainapatra for insufficiency of stamp  duty has been cured by the said impounding order  and in view of the provision of section 35 of the  Stamp Act, 1899 this Court finds that the impugneg  Bainapatra was competent to be admitted jpy,  evidence in this proceeding. Moreover, in view qf  the provision of section 36 of the Stamp Act, 1899  and the decision of the case reported in 39 DLR 243,  this Court finds that the appellate Court correctly  considered that the said Bainapatra as admissible in  evidence, Therefore, the argument that the  Bainapatra has been correctly admitted into  evidence by the trial Court as well as appellate  Court and the question of insufficiency of the stamp  duty has been properly addressed. title: State Acquisition & Tenancy Act. 1950 [XXVIII of 1951]
section: Section 96(4)—The Court of appeal below  without reversing the finding of facts relating to  service of summons arrived at by the trial Court  most erroneously held that without examining  opposite party No.21 Nurul Huda as to the date of  knowledge, the opposite party No.23 Abul Quashem  failed to prove the date of knowledge. section: Compcnsmion—Damnges in case of fatal  accidents-‘Life is a bundle of incident. Every child  s born with expectation of life and with consti-  wtional guaranteed right of basic requirements for  Jiving. Death is inevitable but premature death in  whatever form is not expected and cannot be  consoled. Accidental death also a premature death.  Government is answerable to all such premature  geath 2s Government is to protect the citizen and is  responsible for the life of a citizen. Bangladesh  Beverage Industries Ltd vs Rowshan Akhter (Civil) 483    Constitution Fourth Schedule—The  insertion of Paragraph 18 is anything but an  amendment of the Constitution, rather, this  paragraph was thrust into the Fourth Schedule in an  effort to legalise what were the most illegal  activities of the usurpers and dictators who ruled  Bangladesh during the period from August 15, 1975  to April 9, 1979. Italian Marble Works Lid vs  Bangladesh (Spl. Original) 700    Doctrine of Stare Decisis—Stare Decisis—  The "Doctrine of Stare Decisis" postulates that a  longstanding decision of the Court which has  consistently been followed should not be upturned.  When a decision has been followed in several cases,  its binding effect should not be disturbed merely on  the ground that any particular aspect had not been  expressly considered, M Fransis P Rojario alias  Babu vs State (Criminal) 355    Money medering—-‘Moncy laundering'  was an offence under Money Laundering Prevention  Act, 2002 and that the punishment provided for by  Money Laundering Prevention Act 2009 is not  greater than that of Money Laundering Prevention  Act, 2002. Therefore, there is no chance of prejudice  to the petitioner. Tarique Rahman vs Bangladesh  (Special Original) 524    Motive—It is well settled that the prosecution  is not bound to prove motive and their failure to  prove motive attributed does not cast any doubt as to  the prosecution case.State vs Azam Reza (Cri) 399    Murder—It is well established that the  deceased was done to death. After intentionally  causing the death of the deceased, in order to colour  such homicidal death as suicidal one the dead body  was hanged. The prosecution could prove beyond all  reasonable doubt that the offence of murder was  committed.Stare vs Azam Reza (Criminal) 399    New Warrant of Precedence—The respon-  dent No.l is directed to make a new Warrant of  Precedence in accordance with the 8(eight) point  directives mentioned in the body of the judgment  within a period of 60(sixty) days from the date of  receipt of a copy thereof and to place the District  Judges, Members of the Judicial Service holding  equivalent judicial posts of the District Judges,  Additional District Judges, Chief Judicial Magis-  trates and Chief Metropolitan Magistrates in  appropriate places in the Table of the new Warrant  of Precedence. Ataur Rahman vs Bangladesh (Spl.    Original) 329    Oath of Office—It should be noted that the  oath of office, an individual Judge takes at the time  of his elevation to the Bench, is a personal one and  each individual Judge declares it taking upon  himself, the obligation to ‘preserve, protect and  defend the Constitution®. It is an obligation cast                  upon each individual Judge. Each individual Judge  himself remain oath-bound to fulfil his own  obligation under the Constitution. This obligation  under the oath is personal and remains so upon him,  every day, every week, every month, every year,  during his tenure as a such Judge. His all other  obligations are subject 10 his Oath and the Constitu-  tion.Italian Marble Works Lid vs Bangladesh (Spl.  Original] 700      Observations—Any  revision  of  the  impugned Warrant of Precedence is required or if a  question arises as to framing of a new Warrant of  Precedence altogether, then the Prime Minster will  have the final say on the matter subject to any  Court in this case. Araur Rahman vs Bangladesh  spl Original) 329    Precedence—As per the impugned Warrant  of Precedence, the Table will be observed with  respect o the precedence of persons named therein.  So the meaning of the word 'precedence’ is very  crucial relating 10 the placement of the District  Judges in the said Table. 'Precedence’ means the  order or priority in place or time observed by or for  persons of different status (such as political  dignitaries) on the basis of rank during ceremonial  events and another meaning of the word s generally  the act or state of going before something else  according 1o some system of priorities.    "Precedence’ means priority and that priority is  necessarily and essentially predicated upon one's  status. The meaning of ‘status' js g person's legal  condition, whether personal or proprietary; the sum  total of a person's legal rights, duties, liabilities and  other legal relations, or any particular group of them  separately considered. So while formulating or  making the Table of the Warrant of Precedence, the  status of a functionary, either constitutional or  public, cannot be sneezed at. But in the impugned                   Warrant of precedence some functionaries ha  been placed far below others in derogation to their  dignity, status and priority. Ataur Rahmq,, by  Bangladesh (Spl. Original) 284    Surveyor and Consultant—There are  positive laws and rules concerning PSI Agency in  minute details and those Laws and Rules portrait  service rendered by PSI Agency as "Surveyor”. But  nowhere in those Laws and Rules it could be found  that there has been any deliberation given in any  manner highlighting the PSI Agency as  "Consultant".
